Expectation1: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation1: The carpenter is building custom cabinetry and needs to collaborate with other construction professionals to complete the project on time
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: An optional, drop-in adult education class on a general topic is scheduled.
Story:
I wiped the sawdust from my hands, glancing at the clock on the workshop wall. The cabinetry project was behind schedule, and the electrician was waiting for me to finish the framework so he could install the wiring. My phone buzzed—a reminder for the adult education class at the synagogue. It was an optional session, but I knew several congregants were looking forward to discussing the week’s Torah portion with me. I could almost hear their voices, eager for guidance and insight.

But here, in the workshop, my team depended on me. If I left now, the project would stall, and the client—already anxious—would be disappointed. Yet, as a rabbi, I felt a deep responsibility to be present for my community, to teach and inspire, even if the class was not mandatory. My mind raced, torn between the tangible demands of wood and nails and the spiritual needs of my congregation. I stood in the middle of the sawdust-strewn floor, heart pounding, feeling the weight of both callings pressing in from either side.
